person_639.name: Johann RudolfGlauber
person_639.description: German-Dutch alchemist and chemist. He discovered sodium sulphate in 1625 which was named 'Glauber's salt'.

person_836.name: ChristopherGlaser
person_836.description: a pharmaceutical chemist of the 17th century, the mineral glaserite is named after him.

person_761.name: Louis XIV
person_761.description: King of France from 1643 until death - the 'Sun King'.

person_847.name: Roger JosephBoscovich
person_847.description: Physicist, astronomer and mathematician born in Croatia but lived and worked mainly in Italy and France. Boscovich's work makes him one of the forerunners of atomic theory.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_848.name: FrancescoPetrarch
person_848.description: An Italian poet and scholar, famous for his love sonnets. Davy wrote a poem called 'Vaucluse' inspired by Petrarch's poetry on the river Sorgue and Vaucluse valley in the Provence region of France and called him the 'bard of provence' in another poem, which John Davy published with the title 'Banks of the Rhone'.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_377.name: JohnMayow
person_377.description: Cornish physiologist and chemist, investigated respiration especially. FRSL.

person_839.name: Jean-BaptisteColbert
person_839.description: a French statesman who served as First Minister of State from 1661 until his death in 1683 under the rule of King Louis XIV. He founded the Academy of Sciences in Paris.

person_811.name: NicolasLemery
person_811.description: French chemist, born at Rouen. He was one of the first to develop theories on acid-base chemistry.

person_840.name: LouisLemery
person_840.description: The son of scientist Nicolas Lemery, Louis was appointed physician at the Hôtel-Dieu de Paris in 1710, and became demonstrator of chemistry at the Jardin du Roi in 1731.

person_388.name: Georg ErnstStahl
person_388.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_427.name: Étienne FrançoisGeoffroy
person_427.description: French physician and chemist, best known for his 1718 affinity tables. ForMemRSL.

person_615.name: Jean-Baptiste deSénac
person_615.description: French physician who made extensive studies of the heart.

person_279.name: SlareFrederick
person_279.description: Physician and chemist who worked for Robert Boyle. FRSL.

person_623.name: OleBorch
person_623.description: Danish royal physician who taught Nicolas Steno.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_021.name: StephenHales
person_021.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

person_231.name: JosephBlack
person_231.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

person_033.name: Torbern OlafBergman
person_033.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

person_622.name: DavidMacbride
person_622.description: Irish physician, medical writer and lecturer who contributed to the understanding of scurvy. His Experimental Essays (1764) combined the gas theories of Joseph Black and Sir John Pringle.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_348.name: JanIngenhousz
person_348.description: Dutch-born British physiologist, biologist and chemist. He was one of the discoverers of the process of photosynthesis. FRSL.

place_1031.name: Jakarta
place_1031.description: formerly Batavia, the capital and largest metropolis of Indonesia.

place_718.name: Grotto del Cane
place_718.description: A cave by the Lake of Agnano, in southern Italy, that has a high concentration of carbon dioxide. Dogs were used to demonstrate this as a kind of tourist attraction, which the Shelleys refused to allow when they visited.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

otherwork_219.name: Histoire de l'Academie Royale des Sciences
otherwork_219.author: Wilhelm Homberg
